text: I. Background
label: H3

text: On November 29, 2002, the Office of Water Resources (“OWR”) issued, as a
label: BODY

text: final permit, RIPDES RI 0023558 (“Permit”)1 to the Sakonnet Point Club, Inc. (“SPC”).
label: BODY

text: The SPC proposes to build a multi-purpose yacht club and marina on Bluff Head
label: BODY

text: Avenue in Little Compton, Rhode Island.  The Permit regulates discharge from a
label: BODY

text: reverse osmosis treatment system designed to desalinize well water and thereby
label: BODY

text: provide potable freshwater to service the needs of SPC.  The source of the brackish
label: BODY

text: water to be desalinized is from three deep bedrock wells on the property.  The Permit
label: BODY

text: will allow the discharge of concentrated brackish groundwater from the reverse
label: BODY

text: osmosis treatment system that consists of pre-filtration, reverse osmosis and ultraviolet
label: BODY

text: disinfection.  No discharge of chemicals used in cleaning or sanitizing the pretreatment
label: BODY

text: of feed water or coagulation treatment is allowed under the permit.  The maximum daily
label: BODY

text: discharge permitted is three thousand (3,000) gallons per day.  The discharge will exit
label: BODY

text: through a pipe and diffuser into the Sakonnet River.
label: BODY

text: From July 17, 2002 to August 20, 2002, OWR solicited public comment on the
label: BODY

text: draft permit.  Mary W. Johnson and John D. Karlsson (“Petitioners”) submitted
label: BODY

text: numerous comments and raised several issues during this phase of the permit
label: BODY

text: process.  Issuance of the Permit was accompanied by a response to public comments
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Before proceeding further, I will address Applicant’s oral motion, joined in by
label: BODY

text: OWR and made at the close of Petitioners’ case, that judgment as a matter of law be
label: BODY

text: granted in Applicant’s favor. Petitioners objected, argument was heard and I reserved
label: BODY

text: ruling on the motion until this decision was rendered. Applicant analogized the motion
label: BODY

text: to Super.R.Civ.P. Rule 50 (a)(1) wherein a hearing justice presiding over a jury trial
label: BODY

text: may grant a party's motion for judgment as a matter of law after "a party has been fully
label: BODY

text: heard on an issue and there is no legally sufficient evidentiary basis for a reasonable
label: BODY

text: jury to find for that party on that issue." Counsel argued that Petitioners failed to
label: BODY

text: establish a prima facie case and the Applicant and OWR were entitled to judgment as
label: BODY

text: a matter of law.
label: BODY

text: In considering this motion, I am required to "consider[s] the evidence in the light
label: BODY

text: most favorable to the nonmoving party, without weighing the evidence or evaluating the
label: BODY

text: credibility of witnesses, and draw[s] from the record all reasonable inferences that
label: BODY

text: support the position of the nonmoving party. * * * If, after such a review, there remain

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: III.
label: BODY

text: Did OWR fail to meet the requirements of the Rhode Island Water Quality
label: BODY

text: Regulations 8.D.(1).(f) and (g) in issuing this Permit?
label: BODY

text: Water Quality Regulation 8.D.(1).(f)
label: BODY

text: WQR 8.D.(1).(f) allows the Director to recognize a mixing zone at the discharge
label: BODY

text: site on a case-by-case basis. The mixing zone must meet the minimum conditions set
label: BODY

text: forth in WQR 8.D.(1).(f) which sets the minimum narrative criteria for a mixing zone,
label: BODY

text: including its size, shape and dimension. The Rule provides:
label: BODY

text: (f).  Non-thermal Mixing Zones - In the case of non-thermal discharges, in
label: BODY

text: applying these standards the Director may recognize, where appropriate, a
label: BODY

text: limited acute and/or chronic mixing zone(s) on a case-by-case basis.  The
label: BODY

text: locations, size and shape of these zones shall provide for a maximum protection
label: BODY

text: of fish and wildlife.
label: BODY

text: A mixing zone is defined by Rule 7of the Water Quality Regulations as a “limited
label: BODY

text: area or volume in the immediate vicinity of a discharge where mixing occurs and the
label: BODY

text: receiving surface water quality is not required to meet applicable standards or criteria,
label: BODY

text: RE:   SAKONNET POINT CLUB, INC.
label: BODY

text: AAD No. 02-007/WRA
label: BODY

text: PERMIT NO. RI0023558
label: BODY

text: Page 11
label: BODY

text: provided the minimum conditions described in Rule 8.D.1.(e)3 and 8.D.1.(f) of these
label: BODY

text: regulations are attained”.
label: BODY

text: Petitioners maintain that the permit fails to meet the mandates of WQR 8.D.(1).(f)
label: BODY

text: because a limited and/or chronic mixing zone is not appropriate in this location and the
label: BODY

text: permit does not provide for the maximum protection of fish and wildlife.  They further
label: BODY

text: contend that, to meet the mandate of “maximum protection”, OWR should have required
label: BODY

text: whole effluent toxicity (WET) testing.
label: BODY

text: Establishment of the mixing zone, a crucial issue in this case, was discussed
label: BODY

text: extensively by Mr. Liberti. As part of the permit process, the Applicant submits a plan
label: BODY

text: detailing the proposed discharge system and supplying OWR with dilution calculations
label: BODY

text: and other information to establish a mixing zone compliant with applicable regulations
label: BODY

text: and to support issuance of the permit.  In this case, Applied Science Associates, on
label: BODY

text: behalf of Applicant, evaluated the proposed system and used an EPA-sponsored
label: BODY

text: model, the CORMIX model, to evaluate the dilution that would occur in the vicinity of
label: BODY

text: the discharge.  As is routine with permit applications, Applicant’s consultants did initial
label: BODY

text: model runs evaluating dilution of the effluent and how it would vary over the tidal cycle.
label: BODY

text: Those calculations are set forth in Exhibit A3. OWR then reviews the Application to
label: BODY

text: ensure compliance with the Regulations.
label: BODY

text: In ultimately establishing a mixing zone that meets the Clean Water Act and
label: BODY

text: Rhode Island’s Water Quality Regulations, OWR utilizes portions of the Technical
label: BODY

text: Support Document for Water Quality-Based Toxics Control (“TSD”).  The TSD is a
label: BODY

text: guidance document prepared by EPA that discusses methodologies for evaluating
label: BODY

text: toxics in the water column. As a guidance document, the TSD is not binding and OWR
label: BODY

text: may exercise discretion in applying portions of the TSD in evaluating potential permits.
label: BODY

text: The specific portions used by OWR, both on a routine basis and for this permit, were
label: BODY

text: the sections that describe the establishment of mixing zones consistent with the Clean
label: BODY

text: Water Act and the reasonable potential of a discharge to cause violations of water
label: BODY

text: quality criteria.  Mr. Liberti was involved in reviewing and approving the permit
label: BODY

text: development document prepared by his staff and under his supervision.  Specifically,
label: BODY

text: he reviewed the establishment of the mixing zone, the evaluation of reasonable
label: BODY

text: potential for exceeding water quality regulations and the coordination with the Division
label: BODY

text: of Fish and Wildlife concerning fisheries issues.  According to testimony by Mr. Liberti, a
label: BODY

text: mixing zone is an area in which it is expected that water quality criteria will not be met
label: BODY

text: until the edge of that zone.  Moreover, it is an area in which lethality to benthic and
label: BODY

text: stationary organisms is not only allowed, but expected. Although mixing zones are
label: BODY

text: allowed, Mr. Liberti acknowledged that the Regulations require that the location, size and
label: BODY

text: shape of the acute and chronic mixing zones provide for the maximum protection of fish
label: BODY

text: and wildlife.  It was his conclusion that the permit meets these regulatory requirements.
label: BODY

text: Mr. Liberti explained OWR’s interpretation of the phrase “maximum protection”.
label: BODY

text: He stated that this phrase is not interpreted by OWR as prohibiting a discharge.  He
label: BODY

text: testified that, if that were the intent of the regulation, it would have been written in a way
label: BODY

text: that allowed a discharge only when other alternatives were infeasible.  This is not, in his
label: BODY

text: opinion, the intent of the Regulation nor is it how OWR has consistently interpreted and
label: BODY

text: applied the phrase “maximum protection”.  When OWR allows a mixing zone, “maximum
label: BODY

text: protection” is accomplished by requiring specific permit conditions, on a case-by-case
label: BODY

text: basis, while typically considering the location of the discharge, the size of the discharge,
label: BODY

text: flow limits and other factors that would provide greater degrees of protection.
label: BODY

text: For this permit, Mr. Liberti testified that OWR followed that routine process and
label: BODY

text: considered the location of the discharge.  OWR required that the discharge be located in
label: BODY

text: an area that is well flushed and therefore required that the discharge pipe be placed
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: outside the breakwater on the ocean side and not inside the harbor where flushing would
label: BODY

text: be minimal.  The permitted location promotes rapid mixing of effluent.  The discharge
label: BODY

text: pipe is located twenty feet from the seawall to encourage better mixing and a diffuser
label: BODY

text: pipe is required, again to promote more rapid mixing with the receiving waters.
label: BODY

text: In determining the size and shape of the mixing zone, Mr. Liberti testified that
label: BODY

text: OWR achieved “maximum protection” as required by the regulations in at least two ways.
label: BODY

text: First, in determining the size of the mixing zone, and as discussed earlier, OWR
label: BODY

text: employed the EPA recommended method of computing mixing zone diameters and
label: BODY

text: chose the most stringent acute mixing zone diameter of 7.9 feet.  Secondly, although a
label: BODY

text: chronic mixing zone radius of 450' is allowable under the Regulations, OWR mandated
label: BODY

text: that both acute and chronic water quality criteria be met at the edge of the more limited
label: BODY

text: 7.9 foot radius.
label: BODY

text: Other requirements were added by OWR which, according to Mr. Liberti, further
label: BODY

text: accomplished the “maximum protection” required by the regulations.  OWR prohibited
label: BODY

text: the use of chemicals in the discharge and prohibited use of anti-scaling compounds.
label: BODY

text: Significantly, OWR set a maximum daily discharge of three thousand (3,000) gallons
label: BODY

text: per day -- less than half the volume requested and supported by Applicant in its
label: BODY

text: RIPDES application.  The effect of the lower volume discharge is to increase the
label: BODY

text: Applicant’s predicted dilution factor by two, and reduce by half, the percentage of
label: BODY

text: allowable pollutant concentrations.
label: BODY

text: Petitioners next maintain that the OWR failed to meet regulatory mandates by
label: BODY

text: failing to require whole effluent toxicity testing (“WET testing”). WET testing is the means
label: BODY

text: suggested by Petitioners to best assess the effects, if any, of additive toxicity of copper,
label: BODY

text: nickel and arsenic on the marine organisms in the receiving waters. WET testing
label: BODY

text: evaluates interactions between all pollutants in a discharge rather than focusing on one
label: BODY

text: specific constituent in the discharge. It measures the response of aquatic organisms
label: BODY

text: AAD No. 02-007/WRA

text: PERMIT NO. RI0023558
label: BODY

text: Page 14
label: BODY

text: exposed to the subject effluent in both acute and chronic tests.  Petitioners maintain that
label: BODY

text: WET testing would provide a better overall picture of the toxicity of the discharge than
label: BODY

text: would the methods included in the Permit. They assert that the OWR failed to comply
label: BODY

text: with its Regulations by not requiring WET testing of the effluent for this Permit.
label: BODY

text: Mary W. Johnson testified on behalf of Petitioners.  Ms. Johnson was qualified as
label: BODY

text: an expert in bioassays and lobster toxicology.  Ms. Johnson was employed as a
label: BODY

text: biological laboratory technician for the EPA from 1973 to 1993 and from that date (to the
label: BODY

text: present) she holds the position of technical information specialist.  She conducted toxicity
label: BODY

text: bioassays on marine organisms including lobsters and lobster larvae.  Specifically, Ms.
label: BODY

text: Johnson testified on behalf of Petitioners concerning bioassays she has conducted on
label: BODY

text: lobster larvae and mysid shrimp (a test species which she stated would be species
label: BODY

text: protective for crustaceans).  It was Ms. Johnson’s testimony that OWR should require
label: BODY

text: testing that would measure the combined effect of metals present in the discharge rather
label: BODY

text: than the effects of a single metal on an organism.  Moreover, her testimony was that in
label: BODY

text: doing such testing, OWR should require that mysid shrimp be the test species.
label: BODY

text: To further support the need for WET testing, Ms. Johnson testified that the
label: BODY

text: seawater at the site of the discharge had little complexing ability with regard to metals.
label: BODY

text: According to Ms. Johnson, compared to the waters of the upper bay, the receiving
label: BODY

text: waters have little ability to bind metals and make them unavailable to be taken up by
label: BODY

text: organisms within the mixing zone.  As a result, she testified that the metals discharged to
label: BODY

text: the receiving waters would be more bio-available to organisms, including lobster, thereby
label: BODY

text: increasing the toxicity of the discharge.
label: BODY

text: The issue of additive toxicity was also addressed by Dr. McCay.  She agreed with
label: BODY

text: Petitioners that metals can have additive effects.  She stated that EPA is currently
label: BODY

text: working on development of criteria for additive metal concentrations and effects.  There
label: BODY

text: is a formula currently in use by EPA and others in the field which she has used, and
label: BODY

text: RE:   SAKONNET POINT CLUB, INC.
label: BODY

text: AAD No. 02-007/WRA
label: BODY

text: PERMIT NO. RI0023558
label: BODY

text: Page 15
label: BODY

text: published papers on, which evaluates the additive toxicity of the expected metals. The
label: BODY

text: method is a “Toxic Unit Analysis” whereby the sum of the toxic units for each pollutant
label: BODY

text: that might have an additive effect is totaled.  To be acceptable, the added units must
label: BODY

text: total less than one (<1.0).  Dr. McCay performed this computation adding the toxic units
label: BODY

text: for copper, nickel and arsenic, as compared to the acute criteria (CMC), and determined
label: BODY

text: that at the edge of the mixing zone the sum of toxic use is less than one (.98).  Based on
label: BODY

text: this analysis, she concluded that there would be no additive effects outside the mixing
label: BODY

text: zone. She performed a similar analysis as compared to the chronic criteria (CCC) and
label: BODY

text: concluded that the sum of toxic use at the edge of the mixing zone was likewise less
label: BODY

text: than one (.65). Because of this comparison, and the fact that the Water Quality Criteria
label: BODY

text: conservatively assume that all dissolved metals are bioavailable, Dr. McCay concluded
label: BODY

text: that the criteria used are protective of not having additive effects from the metals present
label: BODY

text: in the effluent. Moreover, these results were achieved using the Applicant’s proposed
label: BODY

text: maximum daily discharge of 7,500 gallons per day, not the Permit-imposed maximum of
label: BODY

text: 3,000 gallons per day.  As a result, Dr. McCay indicated that these numbers are very
label: BODY

text: conservative and would likely be cut in half using the maximum daily discharge set by the
label: BODY

text: Permit.
label: BODY

text: Mr. Liberti testified that in reviewing the Permit application OWR considered
label: BODY

text: additive toxicity.  This concern is addressed in the TSD, which outlines three control
label: BODY

text: approaches to protection of aquatic life.  It is, again, EPA guidance that recommends that
label: BODY

text: states, in their water quality regulations, look at a) chemical specific numbers for the
label: BODY

text: protection of aquatic life; b) whole effluent toxicity testing (WET Testing) and; c)
label: BODY

text: biosurveys of the waterbody or a biocriteria approach.  With regard to this permit, OWR,
label: BODY

text: in its discretion, applied chemical specific numbers.  WET testing was not required
label: BODY

text: because it is OWR’s position that whole effluent toxicity requirements are met by the
label: BODY

text: narrative standards adopted in the Water Quality Regulations.

text: Mr. Liberti’s testimony was clear that WET testing is not mandated by existing
label: BODY

text: Regulations.  What is required, is that Applicant meet the narrative standards set forth in
label: BODY

text: the Regulations.  In evaluating and issuing the Permit, OWR determined that the
label: BODY

text: Applicant met those properly adopted standards.  Mr. Liberti further explained that
label: BODY

text: because EPA retains oversight responsibilities for RIPDES Permits, the Permit was
label: BODY

text: forwarded to Bob Mendoza, manager of EPA’s Region I Rhode Island unit.  EPA’s role
label: BODY

text: in a delegated state, such as Rhode Island, is to review the permit and “overfile” should
label: BODY

text: they determine that any conditions or terms of the permit are not appropriate under the
label: BODY

text: Regulations.  Although there was some communication during the Permit process,
label: BODY

text: ultimately EPA did not make any comments concerning the permit limits or the
label: BODY

text: establishment of the mixing zone nor did they “overfile” on the Permit.
label: BODY

text: Petitioners questioned Mr. Liberti extensively, but his conclusion that the permit
label: BODY

text: issued by OWR provided the “maximum protection” contemplated by the Regulation did
label: BODY

text: not waver. Although it has been Petitioners’ steadfast position that WET testing is a
label: BODY

text: better approach and should be employed, no evidence was placed on the record to
label: BODY

text: establish that WET testing is required by applicable regulations or that OWR failed to
label: BODY

text: meet existing water quality regulations or otherwise abused its discretion by following the
label: BODY

text: narrative standards adopted in its Regulations.  Petitioners failed to prove that OWR did
label: BODY

text: not comply with WQR 8.D.(1).(f) in issuing this Permit.

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY
